text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full-page miniature occupying nearly the entire folio, framed at top by a gothic arcade; a single horizontal register with an architectural archivolt at the summit and the image filling margin to margin; no running text around the picture except a small chapter rubric (‘Xiv’) above the frame

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for all halos and the framing arcade, emphasizing divine figures and architecture. Deep ultramarine backgrounds set off the figures, while vermilion and green alternate in drapery to create rhythmic color balance. White highlighting on folds and gold punching in the blue field provide texture. Pigments remain well-preserved with minimal flaking and restrained oxidation of lead white.

features: Horizontal bisected composition with upper register of standing figures and lower register of a kneeling disciple at table
Central figure elevated both physically and by scale, flanked by mirrored groupings of attendants
Architectural arcade with pointed trefoiled arches frames the scene and reinforces symmetry
Table serves as a strong horizontal axis dividing the two levels
Gestural and visual axes converge on the central figure

decorative_elements: Gothic micro-architecture with pinnacles, crockets, and diapered tile roof in the archivolt
Diapered blue background sprinkled with white quatrefoil stars
Tablecloth patterned with repeating geometric motifs in red and gold
Punch-work in gold leaf within the arches
Small fleur-de-lis and foliate terminals atop spandrels

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill‐pen outlines in dark brown ink, with bold outer contours and finely incised interior detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle parallel hatching in drapery folds and white lead highlights to model form
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without true linear perspective; figures overlap to indicate depth but size is driven by importance

content_theme.scene_description: A single scene shows Christ en gloire surrounded by six apostles in the upper half of the image, beneath a pointed gothic arcade. Christ stands at center, his right hand raised in blessing and his left supporting a large dish bearing a severed, haloed head (interpreted here as a theological emblem of the Eucharist). He is flanked symmetrically by three apostles on each side, each with individualized facial features and hair types, wearing alternating red and blue cloaks edged with gold. Below, one disciple kneels at a richly patterned table laden with chalices, jugs, platters and stylized utensils, gazing upward in recognition. The disciple’s red mantle and blue tunic echo the palette above. All figures are shoe-less, on a tiled dais that unifies the registers. The table serves as a compositional barrier and link between heaven (Christ and apostles) and earth (the believer receiving the sacrament). The scene emphasizes visual weight toward the center, with all gestural lines and color accents directing the eye to Christ’s blessing hand and the emblematic dish.

architectural: Pointed gothic arcade with trefoil arches

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, extremely smooth, uniform thickness; evidence of professional scraping and pumicing, with visible ruling for framing in plummet
technical_features.preservation_condition: Very good: pigments remain vibrant, gold leaf largely intact; minor abrasion at lower table edge and slight flaking of red pigment in drapery folds
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf in halos and archivolt punch-work
Confident underdrawing visible under UV in drapery folds
Even brush-applied pigment layers with fine brush-stroke texture in facial modeling

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This full-page miniature, likely produced in a high-status Gothic workshop in northern France circa 1250–1275, epitomizes the era’s fusion of architectural framing and devotional imagery. Executed on fine calf vellum with burnished gold and ultramarine, the image served both as a focal point for liturgical meditation and as a visual reinforcement of Eucharistic theology. The hierarchical scaling and symmetrical balance reflect the theological imperative to center Christ as mediator, while the sumptuous materials underscore the patron’s ecclesiastical identity and financial means. Stylistically, the sharp contours, punch-worked gold ground, and rhythmic drapery patterns align with manuscripts associated with the Parisian court school. Thematically, the depiction of Christ holding a severed haloed head in a dish is an unusual conflation of martyrdom imagery and Eucharistic symbolism, perhaps drawing on typological readings that identify John the Baptist’s sacrificial witness with Christ’s own Passion. The striking use of negative space in the diapered background and the precision of underdrawing suggest a disciplined atelier practice with separate hands for drawing and color. Comparatively, the work resonates with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile in its architectural framing and color palette, yet innovates through its allegorical object—the dish—as a pictorial device. This miniature thus sits at the crossroads of tradition and innovation, embodying Gothic art’s theological depth and technical sophistication.
